text:
These are the words of Nehemiah son of Hacaliah:
It so happened that in the month of Kislev, in the twentieth year, I was in Susa the citadel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hanani, who was one of my relatives, along with some of the men from Judah, came to me, and I asked them about the Jews who had escaped and had survived the exile, and about Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: They said to me, “The remnant that remains from the exile there in the province are experiencing considerable adversity and reproach. The wall of Jerusalem lies breached, and its gates have been burned down!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When I heard these things I sat down abruptly, crying and mourning for several days. I continued fasting and praying before the God of heaven.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, “Please, O Lord God of heaven, great and awesome God, who keeps his loving covenant with those who love him and obey his commandments,
speaker: Narrator

text: may your ear be attentive and your eyes be open to hear the prayer of your servant that I am praying to you today throughout both day and night on behalf of your servants the Israelites. I am confessing the sins of the Israelites that we have committed against you—both I myself and my family have sinned.
speaker: Narrator

text: We have behaved corruptly against you, not obeying the commandments, the statutes, and the judgments that you commanded your servant Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please recall the word you commanded your servant Moses: ‘If you act unfaithfully, I will scatter you among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if you repent and obey my commandments and do them, then even if your dispersed people are in the most remote location, I will gather them from there and bring them to the place I have chosen for my name to reside.’
speaker: Narrator

text: They are your servants and your people, whom you have redeemed by your mighty strength and by your powerful hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Please, Lord, listen attentively to the prayer of your servant and to the prayer of your servants who take pleasure in showing respect to your name. Grant your servant success today and show compassion to me in the presence of this man.”
Now I was cupbearer for the king.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then in the month of Nisan, in the twentieth year of King Artaxerxes, when wine was brought to me, I took the wine and gave it to the king. Previously I had not been depressed in the king’s presence.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the king said to me, “Why do you appear to be depressed when you aren’t sick? What can this be other than sadness of heart?” This made me very fearful.
speaker: Narrator

text: I replied to the king, “O king, live forever! Why would I not appear dejected when the city with the graves of my ancestors lies desolate and its gates destroyed by fire?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The king responded, “What is it you are seeking?” Then I quickly prayed to the God of heaven
speaker: Narrator

text: and said to the king, “If the king is so inclined and if your servant has found favor in your sight, dispatch me to Judah, to the city with the graves of my ancestors, so that I can rebuild it.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the king, with his consort sitting beside him, replied, “How long would your trip take, and when would you return?” Since the king was pleased to send me, I gave him a time.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to the king, “If the king is so inclined, let him give me letters for the governors of Trans-Euphrates that will enable me to travel safely until I reach Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and a letter for Asaph the keeper of the king’s nature preserve, so that he will give me timber for beams for the gates of the fortress adjacent to the temple and for the city wall and for the house to which I go.” So the king granted me these requests, for the good hand of my God was on me.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I went to the governors of Trans-Euphrates, and I presented to them the letters from the king. The king had sent with me officers of the army and horsemen.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Sanballat the Horonite and Tobiah the Ammonite official heard all this, they were very displeased that someone had come to seek benefit for the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I came to Jerusalem. When I had been there for three days,
speaker: Narrator

text: I got up during the night, along with a few men who were with me. But I did not tell anyone what my God was putting on my heart to do for Jerusalem. There were no animals with me, except for the one I was riding.
speaker: Narrator

text: I proceeded through the Valley Gate by night, in the direction of the Well of the Dragons and the Dung Gate, inspecting the walls of Jerusalem that had been breached and its gates that had been destroyed by fire.
speaker: Narrator

text: I passed on to the Gate of the Well and the King’s Pool, where there was not enough room for my animal to pass with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I continued up the valley during the night, inspecting the wall. Then I turned back and came to the Valley Gate, and so returned.
speaker: Narrator

text: The officials did not know where I had gone or what I had been doing, for up to this point I had not told any of the Jews or the priests or the nobles or the officials or the rest of the workers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said to them, “You see the problem that we have—Jerusalem is desolate and its gates are burned. Come on! Let’s rebuild the wall of Jerusalem so that this reproach will not continue.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I related to them how the good hand of my God was on me and what the king had said to me. Then they replied, “Let’s begin rebuilding right away!” So they readied themselves for this good project.
speaker: Narrator

text: But when Sanballat the Horonite, Tobiah the Ammonite official, and Geshem the Arab heard all this, they derided us and expressed contempt toward us. They said, “What is this you are doing? Are you rebelling against the king?”
speaker: Narrator

text: I responded to them by saying, “The God of heaven will prosper us. We his servants will start the rebuilding. But you have no just or ancient right in Jerusalem.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Eliashib the high priest and his priestly colleagues arose and built the Sheep Gate. They dedicated it and erected its doors, working as far as the Tower of the Hundred and the Tower of Hananel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Jericho built adjacent to it, and Zaccur son of Imri built adjacent to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sons of Hassenaah rebuilt the Fish Gate. They laid its beams and positioned its doors, its bolts, and its bars.
speaker: Narrator

text: Meremoth son of Uriah, the son of Hakoz, worked on the section adjacent to them. Meshullam son of Berechiah the son of Meshezabel worked on the section next to them. And Zadok son of Baana worked on the section adjacent to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Tekoa worked on the section adjacent to them, but their town leaders would not assist with the work of their master.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joiada son of Paseah and Meshullam son of Besodeiah worked on the Jeshanah Gate. They laid its beams and positioned its doors, its bolts, and its bars.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adjacent to them worked Melatiah the Gibeonite and Jadon the Meronothite, who were men of Gibeon and Mizpah. These towns were under the jurisdiction of the governor of Trans-Euphrates.
speaker: Narrator

text: Uzziel son of Harhaiah, a member of the goldsmiths’ guild, worked on the section adjacent to him. Hananiah, a member of the perfumers’ guild, worked on the section adjacent to him. They plastered the city wall of Jerusalem as far as the Broad Wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: Rephaiah son of Hur, head of a half-district of Jerusalem, worked on the section adjacent to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jedaiah son of Harumaph worked on the section adjacent to them opposite his house, and Hattush son of Hashabneiah worked on the section adjacent to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Malkijah son of Harim and Hasshub son of Pahath Moab worked on another section and the Tower of the Ovens.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallum son of Hallohesh, head of a half-district of Jerusalem, worked on the section adjacent to him, assisted by his daughters.
speaker: Narrator

text: Hanun and the residents of Zanoah worked on the Valley Gate. They rebuilt it and positioned its doors, its bolts, and its bars, in addition to working on 1,500 feet of the wall as far as the Dung Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Malkijah son of Recab, head of the district of Beth Hakkerem, worked on the Dung Gate. He rebuilt it and positioned its doors, its bolts, and its bars.
speaker: Narrator

text: Shallun son of Col-Hozeh, head of the district of Mizpah, worked on the Fountain Gate. He rebuilt it, put on its roof, and positioned its doors, its bolts, and its bars. In addition, he rebuilt the wall of the Pool of Siloam, by the royal garden, as far as the steps that go down from the City of David.
speaker: Narrator

text: Nehemiah son of Azbuk, head of a half-district of Beth Zur, worked after him as far as the tombs of David and the artificial pool and the House of the Warriors.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him the Levites worked—Rehum son of Bani and after him Hashabiah, head of half the district of Keilah, for his district.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him their relatives worked—Binnui son of Henadad, head of a half-district of Keilah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Adjacent to him Ezer son of Jeshua, head of Mizpah, worked on another section, opposite the ascent to the armory at the buttress.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Baruch son of Zabbai worked on another section, from the buttress to the door of the house of Eliashib the high priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Meremoth son of Uriah, the son of Hakkoz, worked on another section from the door of Eliashib’s house to the end of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him the priests worked, men of the nearby district.
speaker: Narrator

text: After them Benjamin and Hasshub worked opposite their house. After them Azariah son of Maaseiah, the son of Ananiah, worked near his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Binnui son of Henadad worked on another section, from the house of Azariah to the buttress and the corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Palal son of Uzai worked opposite the buttress and the tower that protrudes from the upper palace of the court of the guard. After him Pedaiah son of Parosh
speaker: Narrator

text: and the temple servants who were living on Ophel worked up to the area opposite the Water Gate toward the east and the protruding tower.
speaker: Narrator

text: After them the men of Tekoa worked on another section, from opposite the great protruding tower to the wall of Ophel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Above the Horse Gate the priests worked, each in front of his house.
speaker: Narrator

text: After them Zadok son of Immer worked opposite his house, and after him Shemaiah son of Shecaniah, guard at the East Gate, worked.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Hananiah son of Shelemiah, and Hanun, the sixth son of Zalaph, worked on another section. After them Meshullam son of Berechiah worked opposite his quarters.
speaker: Narrator

text: After him Malkijah, one of the goldsmiths, worked as far as the house of the temple servants and the traders, opposite the Inspection Gate, and up to the room above the corner.
speaker: Narrator

text: And between the room above the corner and the Sheep Gate the goldsmiths and traders worked.
speaker: Narrator

text: (3:33) Now when Sanballat heard that we were rebuilding the wall he became angry and was quite upset. He derided the Jews,
speaker: Narrator

text: and in the presence of his colleagues and the army of Samaria he said, “What are these feeble Jews doing? Will they be left to themselves? Will they again offer sacrifice? Will they finish this in a day? Can they bring these burnt stones to life again from piles of dust?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Tobiah the Ammonite, who was close by, said, “If even a fox were to climb up on what they are building, it would break down their wall of stones!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Hear, O our God, for we are despised. Return their reproach on their own head. Reduce them to plunder in a land of exile!
speaker: Narrator

text: Do not cover their iniquity, and do not wipe out their sin from your sight, for they have bitterly offended the builders.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we rebuilt the wall, and the entire wall was joined together up to half its height. The people were enthusiastic in their work.
speaker: Narrator

text: (4:1) When Sanballat, Tobiah, the Arabs, the Ammonites, and the people of Ashdod heard that the restoration of the walls of Jerusalem had moved ahead and that the breaches had begun to be closed, they were very angry.
speaker: Narrator

text: All of them conspired together to move with armed forces against Jerusalem and to create a disturbance in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: So we prayed to our God and stationed a guard to protect against them both day and night.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then those in Judah said, “The strength of the laborers has failed! The debris is so great that we are unable to rebuild the wall.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Our adversaries also boasted, “Before they are aware or anticipate anything, we will come in among them and kill them, and we will bring this work to a halt!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So it happened that the Jews who were living near them came and warned us repeatedly about all the schemes they were plotting against us.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I stationed people at the lower places behind the wall in the exposed places. I stationed the people by families, with their swords, spears, and bows.
speaker: Narrator

text: When I had made an inspection, I stood up and said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, “Don’t be afraid of them. Remember the great and awesome Lord, and fight on behalf of your brothers, your sons, your daughters, your wives, and your families!”
speaker: Narrator

text: It so happened that when our adversaries heard that we were aware of these matters, God frustrated their intentions. Then all of us returned to the wall, each to his own work.
speaker: Narrator

text: From that day forward, half my men were doing the work and half were taking up spears, shields, bows, and body armor. Now the officers were behind all the people of Judah
speaker: Narrator

text: who were rebuilding the wall. Those who were carrying loads did so by keeping one hand on the work and the other on their weapon.
speaker: Narrator

text: The builders, to a man, had their swords strapped to their sides while they were building. But the trumpeter remained with me.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to the nobles, the officials, and the rest of the people, “The work is demanding and extensive, and we are spread out on the wall, far removed from one another.
speaker: Narrator

text: Wherever you hear the sound of the trumpet, gather there with us. Our God will fight for us!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So we worked on, with half holding spears, from dawn till dusk.
speaker: Narrator

text: At that time I instructed the people, “Let every man and his coworker spend the night in Jerusalem and let them be guards for us by night and workers by day.”
speaker: Narrator

text: We did not change clothes—not I, nor my relatives, nor my workers, nor the watchmen who were with me. Each had his weapon, even when getting a drink of water.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then there was a great outcry from the people and their wives against their fellow Jews.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were those who said, “With our sons and daughters, we are many. We must obtain grain in order to eat and stay alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: There were others who said, “We are putting up our fields, our vineyards, and our houses as collateral in order to obtain grain during the famine.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then there were those who said, “We have borrowed money to pay our taxes to the king on our fields and our vineyards.
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, though we share the same flesh and blood as our fellow countrymen and our children are just like their children, still we have found it necessary to subject our sons and daughters to slavery. Some of our daughters have been subjected to slavery, while we are powerless to help, since our fields and vineyards now belong to other people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I was very angry when I heard their outcry and these complaints.
speaker: Narrator

text: I considered these things carefully and then registered a complaint with the wealthy and the officials. I said to them, “Each one of you is seizing the collateral from your own countrymen!” Because of them I called for a great public assembly.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to them, “To the extent possible we have bought back our fellow Jews who had been sold to the Gentiles. But now you yourselves want to sell your own countrymen, so that we can then buy them back!” They were utterly silent, and could find nothing to say.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I said, “The thing that you are doing is wrong! Should you not conduct yourselves in the fear of our God in order to avoid the reproach of the Gentiles who are our enemies?
speaker: Narrator

text: Even I and my relatives and my associates are lending them money and grain. But let us abandon this practice of seizing collateral!
speaker: Narrator

text: This very day return to them their fields, their vineyards, their olive trees, and their houses, along with the interest that you are exacting from them on the money, the grain, the new wine, and the olive oil.”
speaker: Narrator

text: They replied, “We will return these things, and we will no longer demand anything from them. We will do just as you say.” Then I called the priests and made the wealthy and the officials swear to do what had been promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also shook out my garment, and I said, “In this way may God shake out from his house and his property every person who does not carry out this matter. In this way may he be shaken out and emptied!” All the assembly replied, “So be it!” and they praised the Lord. Then the people did as they had promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the day that I was appointed governor in the land of Judah, that is, from the twentieth year until the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes—twelve years in all—neither I nor my relatives ate the food allotted to the governor.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the former governors who preceded me had burdened the people and had taken food and wine from them, in addition to forty shekels of silver. Their associates were also domineering over the people. But I did not behave in this way, due to my fear of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave myself to the work on this wall, without even purchasing a field. All my associates were gathered there for the work.
speaker: Narrator

text: There were 150 Jews and officials who dined with me routinely, in addition to those who came to us from the nations all around us.
speaker: Narrator

text: Every day one ox, six select sheep, and some birds were prepared for me, and every ten days all kinds of wine in abundance. Despite all this I did not require the food allotted to the governor, for the work was demanding on this people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please remember me for good, O my God, for all that I have done for this people.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Sanballat, Tobiah, Geshem the Arab, and the rest of our enemies heard that I had rebuilt the wall and no breach remained in it (even though up to that time I had not positioned doors in the gates),
speaker: Narrator

text: Sanballat and Geshem sent word to me saying, “Come on! Let’s set up a time to meet together at Kephirim in the plain of Ono.” Now they intended to do me harm.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I sent messengers to them saying, “I am engaged in an important work, and I am unable to come down. Why should the work come to a halt when I leave it to come down to you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: They contacted me four times in this way, and I responded the same way each time.
speaker: Narrator

text: The fifth time that Sanballat sent his assistant to me in this way, he had an open letter in his hand.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Written in it were the following words:
“Among the nations it is rumored (and Geshem has substantiated this) that you and the Jews have intentions of revolting, and for this reason you are building the wall. Furthermore, according to these rumors you are going to become their king.
speaker: Narrator

text: You have also established prophets to announce in Jerusalem on your behalf, ‘We have a king in Judah!’ Now the king is going to hear about these rumors. So come on, let’s talk about this.”
speaker: Narrator

text: I sent word back to him, “We are not engaged in these activities you are describing. All of this is a figment of your imagination.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
All of them were wanting to scare us, supposing, “Their hands will grow slack from the work, and it won’t get done.”
So now, strengthen my hands!
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I went to the house of Shemaiah son of Delaiah, the son of Mehetabel. He was confined to his home. He said, “Let’s set up a time to meet in the house of God, within the temple. Let’s close the doors of the temple, for they are coming to kill you. It will surely be at night that they will come to kill you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But I replied, “Should a man like me run away? Would someone like me flee to the temple in order to save his life? I will not go!”
speaker: Narrator

text: I recognized the fact that God had not sent him, for he had spoken the prophecy against me as a hired agent of Tobiah and Sanballat.
speaker: Narrator

text: He had been hired to scare me so that I would do this and thereby sin. They would thus bring reproach on me and I would be discredited.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remember, O my God, Tobiah and Sanballat in light of these actions of theirs—also Noadiah the prophetess and the other prophets who have been trying to scare me!
speaker: Narrator

text: So the wall was completed on the twenty-fifth day of Elul, in just fifty-two days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all our enemies heard and all the nations who were around us saw this, they were greatly disheartened. They knew that this work had been accomplished with the help of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days the aristocrats of Judah repeatedly sent letters to Tobiah, and responses from Tobiah were repeatedly coming to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: For many in Judah had sworn allegiance to him, because he was the son-in-law of Shecaniah son of Arah. His son Jonathan had married the daughter of Meshullam son of Berechiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: They were telling me about his good deeds and then taking back to him the things I said. Tobiah, on the other hand, sent letters in order to scare me.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the wall had been rebuilt and I had positioned the doors, and the gatekeepers, the singers, and the Levites had been appointed,
speaker: Narrator

text: I then put in charge over Jerusalem my brother Hanani and Hananiah the chief of the citadel, for he was a faithful man and feared God more than many do.
speaker: Narrator

text: I said to them, “The gates of Jerusalem must not be opened in the early morning, until those who are standing guard close the doors and lock them. Position residents of Jerusalem as guards, some at their guard stations and some near their homes.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the city was spread out and large, and there were not a lot of people in it. At that time houses had not been rebuilt.
speaker: Narrator

text: My God placed it on my heart to gather the leaders, the officials, and the ordinary people so they could be enrolled on the basis of genealogy. I found the genealogical records of those who had formerly returned. Here is what I found written in that record:
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the people of the province who returned from the captivity of the exiles, whom King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon had forced into exile. They returned to Jerusalem and to Judah, each to his own city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They came with Zerubbabel, Jeshua, Nehemiah, Azariah, Raamiah, Nahamani, Mordecai, Bilshan, Mispereth, Bigvai, Nehum, and Baanah.
The number of Israelite men was as follows:
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Parosh: 2,172;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Shephatiah: 372;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Arah: 652;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Pahath Moab (from the line of Jeshua and Joab): 2,818;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Elam: 1,254;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Zattu: 845;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Zaccai: 760;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Binnui: 648;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bebai: 628;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Azgad: 2,322;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Adonikam: 667;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bigvai: 2,067;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Adin: 655;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Ater (through Hezekiah): 98;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Hashum: 328;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bezai: 324;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Harif: 112;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Gibeon: 95;
speaker: Narrator

text: The men of Bethlehem and Netophah: 188;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Anathoth: 128;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of the family of Azmaveth: 42;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Kiriath Jearim, Kephirah, and Beeroth: 743;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Ramah and Geba: 621;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Micmash: 122;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of Bethel and Ai: 123;
speaker: Narrator

text: the men of the other Nebo: 52;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of the other Elam: 1,254;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Harim: 320;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Jericho: 345;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Lod, Hadid, and Ono: 721;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Senaah: 3,930;
speaker: Narrator

text: The priests: the descendants of Jedaiah (through the family of Jeshua): 973;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Immer: 1,052;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Pashhur: 1,247;
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Harim: 1,017.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Levites: the descendants of Jeshua (through Kadmiel, through the line of Hodaviah): 74.
speaker: Narrator

text: The singers: the descendants of Asaph: 148.
speaker: Narrator

text: The gatekeepers: the descendants of Shallum, the descendants of Ater, the descendants of Talmon, the descendants of Akkub, the descendants of Hatita, and the descendants of Shobai: 138.
speaker: Narrator

text: The temple servants: the descendants of Ziha, the descendants of Hasupha, the descendants of Tabbaoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Keros, the descendants of Sia, the descendants of Padon,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Lebanah, the descendants of Hagabah, the descendants of Shalmai,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Hanan, the descendants of Giddel, the descendants of Gahar,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Reaiah, the descendants of Rezin, the descendants of Nekoda,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Gazzam, the descendants of Uzzah, the descendants of Paseah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Besai, the descendants of Meunim, the descendants of Nephussim,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bakbuk, the descendants of Hakupha, the descendants of Harhur,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Bazluth, the descendants of Mehida, the descendants of Harsha,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Barkos, the descendants of Sisera, the descendants of Temah,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Neziah, the descendants of Hatipha.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of the servants of Solomon: the descendants of Sotai, the descendants of Sophereth, the descendants of Perida,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Jaala, the descendants of Darkon, the descendants of Giddel,
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Shephatiah, the descendants of Hattil, the descendants of Pokereth Hazzebaim, and the descendants of Amon.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the temple servants and the descendants of the servants of Solomon, 392.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the ones who came up from Tel Melah, Tel Harsha, Kerub, Addon, and Immer (although they were unable to certify their family connection or their ancestry, as to whether they were really from Israel):
speaker: Narrator

text: the descendants of Delaiah, the descendants of Tobiah, and the descendants of Nekoda, 642.
speaker: Narrator

text: And from among the priests: the descendants of Hobaiah, the descendants of Hakkoz, and the descendants of Barzillai (who had married a woman from the daughters of Barzillai the Gileadite and was called by that name).
speaker: Narrator

text: They searched for their records in the genealogical materials, but none were found. They were therefore excluded from the priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: The governor instructed them not to eat any of the sacred food until there was a priest who could consult the Urim and Thummim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The entire group numbered 42,360—
speaker: Narrator

text: not counting their 7,337 male and female servants. They also had 245 male and female singers.
speaker: Narrator

text: They had 736 horses, 245 mules,
speaker: Narrator

text: (7:68) 435 camels, and 6,720 donkeys.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the family leaders contributed to the work. The governor contributed to the treasury 1,000 gold drachmas, 50 bowls, and 530 priestly garments.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the family leaders gave to the project treasury 20,000 gold drachmas and 2,200 silver minas.
speaker: Narrator

text: What the rest of the people gave amounted to 20,000 gold drachmas, 2,000 silver minas, and 67 priestly garments.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The priests, the Levites, the gatekeepers, the singers, some of the people, the temple servants, and all the rest of Israel lived in their cities.
When the seventh month arrived and the Israelites were settled in their towns,
speaker: Narrator

text: all the people gathered together in the plaza which was in front of the Water Gate. They asked Ezra the scribe to bring the book of the law of Moses which the Lord had commanded Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Ezra the priest brought the law before the assembly which included men and women and all those able to understand what they heard. (This happened on the first day of the seventh month.)
speaker: Narrator

text: So he read it before the plaza in front of the Water Gate from dawn till noon before the men and women and those children who could understand. All the people were eager to hear the book of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezra the scribe stood on a towering wooden platform constructed for this purpose. Standing near him on his right were Mattithiah, Shema, Anaiah, Uriah, Hilkiah, and Masseiah. On his left were Pedaiah, Mishael, Malkijah, Hashum, Hashbaddanah, Zechariah, and Meshullam.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezra opened the book in plain view of all the people, for he was elevated above all the people. When he opened the book, all the people stood up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezra blessed the Lord, the great God, and all the people replied “Amen! Amen!” as they lifted their hands. Then they bowed down and worshiped the Lord with their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeshua, Bani, Sherebiah, Jamin, Akkub, Shabbethai, Hodiah, Maaseiah, Kelita, Azariah, Jozabad, Hanan, and Pelaiah—all of whom were Levites—were teaching the people the law, as the people remained standing.
speaker: Narrator

text: They read from the book of God’s law, explaining it and imparting insight. Thus the people gained understanding from what was read.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Nehemiah the governor, Ezra the priestly scribe, and the Levites who were imparting understanding to the people said to all of them, “This day is holy to the Lord your God. Do not mourn or weep.” For all the people had been weeping when they heard the words of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: He said to them, “Go and eat delicacies and drink sweet drinks and send portions to those for whom nothing is prepared. For this day is holy to our Lord. Do not grieve, for the joy of the Lord is your strength.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Levites quieted all the people saying, “Be quiet, for this day is holy. Do not grieve.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the people departed to eat and drink and to share their food with others and to enjoy tremendous joy, for they had gained insight in the matters that had been made known to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the second day of the month the family leaders met with Ezra the scribe, together with all the people, the priests, and the Levites, to consider the words of the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: They discovered written in the law that the Lord had commanded through Moses that the Israelites should live in temporary shelters during the festival of the seventh month,
speaker: Narrator

text: and that they should make a proclamation and disseminate this message in all their cities and in Jerusalem: “Go to the hill country and bring back olive branches and branches of wild olive trees, myrtle trees, date palms, and other leafy trees to construct temporary shelters, as it is written.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the people went out and brought these things back and constructed temporary shelters for themselves, each on his roof and in his courtyard and in the courtyards of the temple of God and in the plaza of the Water Gate and the plaza of the Ephraim Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: So all the assembly which had returned from the exile constructed temporary shelters and lived in them. The Israelites had not done so from the days of Joshua son of Nun until that day. Everyone experienced very great joy.
speaker: Narrator

text: Ezra read in the book of the law of God day by day, from the first day to the last. They observed the festival for seven days, and on the eighth day they held an assembly as was required.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the twenty-fourth day of this same month the Israelites assembled; they were fasting and wearing sackcloth, their heads covered with dust.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those truly of Israelite descent separated from all the foreigners, standing and confessing their sins and the iniquities of their ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: For one-fourth of the day they stood in their place and read from the book of the law of the Lord their God, and for another fourth they were confessing their sins and worshiping the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Levites—Jeshua, Binnui, Kadmiel, Shebaniah, Bunni, Sherebiah, Bani, and Kenani—stood on the steps and called out loudly to the Lord their God.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Levites—Jeshua, Kadmiel, Bani, Hashabneiah, Sherebiah, Hodiah, Shebaniah, and Pethahiah—said, “Stand up and bless the Lord your God!”
“May you be blessed, O Lord our God, from age to age. May your glorious name be blessed; may it be lifted up above all blessing and praise.
speaker: Narrator

text: You alone are the Lord. You made the heavens, even the highest heavens, along with all their multitude of stars, the earth and all that is on it, the seas and all that is in them. You impart life to them all, and the multitudes of heaven worship you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are the Lord God who chose Abram and brought him forth from Ur of the Chaldeans. You changed his name to Abraham.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you perceived that his heart was faithful toward you, you established a covenant with him to give his descendants the land of the Canaanites, the Hittites, the Amorites, the Perizzites, the Jebusites, and the Girgashites. You have fulfilled your promise, for you are righteous.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You saw the affliction of our ancestors in Egypt, and you heard their cry at the Red Sea.
speaker: Narrator

text: You performed awesome signs against Pharaoh, against his servants, and against all the people of his land, for you knew that the Egyptians had acted presumptuously against them. You made for yourself a name that is celebrated to this day.
speaker: Narrator

text: You split the sea before them, and they crossed through the sea on dry ground. But you threw their pursuers into the depths, like a stone into surging waters.
speaker: Narrator

text: You guided them with a pillar of cloud by day and with a pillar of fire by night to illumine for them the path they were to travel.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You came down on Mount Sinai and spoke with them from heaven. You provided them with just judgments, true laws, and good statutes and commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: You made known to them your holy Sabbath; you issued commandments, statutes, and laws to them through Moses your servant.
speaker: Narrator

text: You provided bread from heaven for them in their time of hunger, and you brought forth water from the rock for them in their time of thirst. You told them to enter in order to possess the land that you had sworn to give them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But they—our ancestors—behaved presumptuously; they rebelled and did not obey your commandments.
speaker: Narrator

text: They refused to obey and did not recall your miracles that you had performed among them. Instead, they rebelled and appointed a leader to return to their bondage in Egypt. But you are a God of forgiveness, merciful and compassionate, slow to get angry and unfailing in your loyal love. You did not abandon them,
speaker: Narrator

text: even when they made a cast image of a calf for themselves and said, ‘This is your God who brought you up from Egypt,’ or when they committed atrocious blasphemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Due to your great compassion you did not abandon them in the wilderness. The pillar of cloud did not stop guiding them in the path by day, nor did the pillar of fire stop illuminating for them by night the path on which they should travel.
speaker: Narrator

text: You imparted your good Spirit to instruct them. You did not withhold your manna from their mouths; you provided water for their thirst.
speaker: Narrator

text: For forty years you sustained them. Even in the wilderness they never lacked anything. Their clothes did not wear out and their feet did not swell.
speaker: Narrator

text: “You gave them kingdoms and peoples, and you allocated them to every corner of the land. They inherited the land of King Sihon of Heshbon and the land of King Og of Bashan.
speaker: Narrator

text: You multiplied their descendants like the stars of the sky. You brought them to the land you had told their ancestors to enter in order to possess.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their descendants entered and possessed the land. You subdued before them the Canaanites who were the inhabitants of the land. You delivered them into their hand, together with their kings and the peoples of the land, to deal with as they pleased.
speaker: Narrator

text: They captured fortified cities and fertile land. They took possession of houses full of all sorts of good things—wells previously dug, vineyards, olive trees, and fruit trees in abundance. They ate until they were full and grew fat. They enjoyed to the full your great goodness.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Nonetheless they grew disobedient and rebelled against you; they disregarded your law. They killed your prophets who had solemnly admonished them in order to cause them to return to you. They committed atrocious blasphemies.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you delivered them into the hand of their adversaries, who oppressed them. But in the time of their distress they called to you, and you heard from heaven. In your abundant compassion you provided them with deliverers to rescue them from their adversaries.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Then, when they were at rest again, they went back to doing evil before you. Then you abandoned them to their enemies, and they gained dominion over them. When they again cried out to you, in your compassion you heard from heaven and rescued them time and again.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you solemnly admonished them in order to return them to your law, but they behaved presumptuously and did not obey your commandments. They sinned against your ordinances—those by which an individual, if he obeys them, will live. They boldly turned from you; they rebelled and did not obey.
speaker: Narrator

text: You prolonged your kindness with them for many years, and you solemnly admonished them by your Spirit through your prophets. Still they paid no attention, so you delivered them into the hands of the neighboring peoples.
speaker: Narrator

text: However, due to your abundant mercy you did not do away with them altogether; you did not abandon them. For you are a merciful and compassionate God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So now, our God—the great, powerful, and awesome God, who keeps covenant fidelity—do not regard as inconsequential all the hardship that has befallen us—our kings, our leaders, our priests, our prophets, our ancestors, and all your people—from the days of the kings of Assyria until this very day.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are righteous with regard to all that has happened to us, for you have acted faithfully. It is we who have been in the wrong!
speaker: Narrator

text: Our kings, our leaders, our priests, and our ancestors have not kept your law. They have not paid attention to your commandments or your testimonies by which you have solemnly admonished them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Even when they were in their kingdom and benefiting from your incredible goodness that you had lavished on them in the spacious and fertile land you had set before them, they did not serve you, nor did they turn from their evil practices.
speaker: Narrator

text: “So today we are slaves! In the very land you gave to our ancestors to eat its fruit and to enjoy its good things—we are slaves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Its abundant produce goes to the kings you have placed over us due to our sins. They rule over our bodies and our livestock as they see fit, and we are in great distress!
speaker: Narrator

text: (10:1) “Because of all this we are entering into a binding covenant in written form; our leaders, our Levites, and our priests have affixed their names on the sealed document.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
On the sealed documents were the following names:
Nehemiah the governor, son of Hacaliah, along with Zedekiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Seraiah, Azariah, Jeremiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pashhur, Amariah, Malkijah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hattush, Shebaniah, Malluch,
speaker: Narrator

text: Harim, Meremoth, Obadiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Daniel, Ginnethon, Baruch,
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshullam, Abijah, Mijamin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Maaziah, Bilgai, and Shemaiah. These were the priests.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The Levites were as follows:
Jeshua son of Azaniah, Binnui of the sons of Henadad, Kadmiel.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Their colleagues were as follows:
Shebaniah, Hodiah, Kelita, Pelaiah, Hanan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mica, Rehob, Hashabiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zaccur, Sherebiah, Shebaniah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hodiah, Bani, and Beninu.
speaker: Narrator

text:
The leaders of the people were as follows:
Parosh, Pahath Moab, Elam, Zattu, Bani,
speaker: Narrator

text: Bunni, Azgad, Bebai,
speaker: Narrator

text: Adonijah, Bigvai, Adin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ater, Hezekiah, Azzur,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hodiah, Hashum, Bezai,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hariph, Anathoth, Nebai,
speaker: Narrator

text: Magpiash, Meshullam, Hezir,
speaker: Narrator

text: Meshezabel, Zadok, Jaddua,
speaker: Narrator

text: Pelatiah, Hanan, Anaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hoshea, Hananiah, Hasshub,
speaker: Narrator

text: Hallohesh, Pilha, Shobek,
speaker: Narrator

text: Rehum, Hashabnah, Maaseiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Ahiah, Hanan, Anan,
speaker: Narrator

text: Malluch, Harim, and Baanah.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Now the rest of the people—the priests, the Levites, the gatekeepers, the singers, the temple attendants, and all those who have separated themselves from the neighboring peoples because of the law of God, along with their wives, their sons, and their daughters, all of whom are able to understand—
speaker: Narrator

text: hereby participate with their colleagues the town leaders and enter into a curse and an oath to adhere to the law of God which was given through Moses the servant of God, and to obey carefully all the commandments of the Lord our Lord, along with his ordinances and his statutes.
speaker: Narrator

text: “We will not give our daughters in marriage to the neighboring peoples, and we will not take their daughters in marriage for our sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will not buy on the Sabbath or on a holy day from the neighboring peoples who bring their wares and all kinds of grain to sell on the Sabbath day. We will let the fields lie fallow every seventh year, and we will cancel every loan.
speaker: Narrator

text: We accept responsibility for fulfilling the commands to give one third of a shekel each year for the work of the temple of our God,
speaker: Narrator

text: for the loaves of presentation and for the regular grain offerings and regular burnt offerings, for the Sabbaths, for the new moons, for the appointed meetings, for the holy offerings, for the sin offerings to make atonement for Israel, and for all the work of the temple of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: “We—the priests, the Levites, and the people—have cast lots concerning the wood offerings, to bring them to the temple of our God according to our families at the designated times year by year to burn on the altar of the Lord our God, as is written in the law.
speaker: Narrator

text: We also accept responsibility for bringing the firstfruits of our land and the firstfruits of every fruit tree year by year to the temple of the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: We also accept responsibility, as is written in the law, for bringing the firstborn of our sons and our cattle and the firstborn of our herds and of our flocks to the temple of our God, to the priests who are ministering in the temple of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: We will also bring the first of our coarse meal, of our contributions, of the fruit of every tree, of new wine, and of olive oil to the priests at the storerooms of the temple of our God, along with a tenth of the produce of our land to the Levites, for the Levites are the ones who collect the tithes in all the cities where we work.
speaker: Narrator

text: A priest of Aaron’s line will be with the Levites when the Levites collect the tithes, and the Levites will bring up a tenth of the tithes to the temple of our God, to the storerooms of the treasury.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites and the Levites will bring the contribution of the grain, the new wine, and the olive oil to the storerooms where the utensils of the sanctuary are kept, and where the priests who minister stay, along with the gatekeepers and the singers. We will not neglect the temple of our God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the leaders of the people settled in Jerusalem, while the rest of the people cast lots to bring one out of every ten to settle in Jerusalem, the holy city, while the other nine remained in other cities.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people gave their blessing on all the men who volunteered to settle in Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the provincial leaders who settled in Jerusalem. (While other Israelites, the priests, the Levites, the temple attendants, and the sons of the servants of Solomon settled in the cities of Judah, each on his own property in their cities,
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text: and Maaseiah son of Baruch, the son of Col-Hozeh, the son of Hazaiah, the son of Adaiah, the son of Joiarib, the son of Zechariah, from the descendants of Shelah.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sum total of the descendants of Perez who were settling in Jerusalem was 468 exceptional men.
speaker: Narrator

text:
These are the descendants of Benjamin:
Sallu son of Meshullam, the son of Joed, the son of Pedaiah, the son of Kolaiah, the son of Maaseiah, the son of Ithiel, the son of Jeshaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his followers, Gabbai and Sallai—928 in all.
speaker: Narrator

text: Joel son of Zicri was the officer in charge of them, and Judah son of Hassenuah was second-in-command over the city.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the priests:
Jedaiah son of Joiarib, Jakin,
speaker: Narrator

text: Seraiah son of Hilkiah, the son of Meshullam, the son of Zadok, the son of Meraioth, the son of Ahitub, supervisor in the temple of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: and their colleagues who were carrying out work for the temple—822; and Adaiah son of Jeroham, the son of Pelaliah, the son of Amzi, the son of Zechariah, the son of Pashhur, the son of Malkijah,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his colleagues who were heads of families—242; and Amashsai son of Azarel, the son of Ahzai, the son of Meshillemoth, the son of Immer,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his colleagues who were exceptional men—128. The officer over them was Zabdiel the son of Haggedolim.
speaker: Narrator

text:
From the Levites:
Shemaiah son of Hasshub, the son of Azrikam, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Bunni;
speaker: Narrator

text: Shabbethai and Jozabad, leaders of the Levites, were in charge of the external work for the temple of God;
speaker: Narrator

text: Mattaniah son of Mica, the son of Zabdi, the son of Asaph, the praise leader who led in thanksgiving and prayer; Bakbukiah, second among his colleagues; and Abda son of Shammua, the son of Galal, the son of Jeduthun.
speaker: Narrator

text: The sum total of the Levites in the holy city was 284.
speaker: Narrator

text:
And the gatekeepers:
Akkub, Talmon and their colleagues who were guarding the gates—172.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the rest of the Israelites, with the priests and the Levites, were in all the cities of Judah, each on his own property.
speaker: Narrator

text: The temple attendants were living on Ophel, and Ziha and Gishpa were over them.
speaker: Narrator

text: The overseer of the Levites in Jerusalem was Uzzi son of Bani, the son of Hashabiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Mica. He was one of Asaph’s descendants, who were the singers responsible for the service of the temple of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: For they were under royal orders which determined their activity day by day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pethahiah son of Meshezabel, one of the descendants of Zerah son of Judah, was an adviser to the king in every matter pertaining to the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the settlements with their fields, some of the people of Judah settled in Kiriath Arba and its neighboring villages, in Dibon and its villages, in Jekabzeel and its settlements,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Jeshua, in Moladah, in Beth Pelet,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Hazar Shual, in Beer Sheba and its villages,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Ziklag, in Meconah and its villages,
speaker: Narrator

text: in En Rimmon, in Zorah, in Jarmuth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Zanoah, Adullam and their settlements, in Lachish and its fields, and in Azekah and its villages. So they were encamped from Beer Sheba to the Valley of Hinnom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the descendants of Benjamin settled in Geba, Micmash, Aija, Bethel and its villages,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Anathoth, Nob, and Ananiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Hazor, Ramah, and Gittaim,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Hadid, Zeboyim, and Neballat,
speaker: Narrator

text: in Lod, Ono, and the Valley of the Craftsmen.
speaker: Narrator

text: Some of the Judean divisions of the Levites settled in Benjamin.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the priests and Levites who returned with Zerubbabel son of Shealtiel and Jeshua: Seraiah, Jeremiah, Ezra,
speaker: Narrator

text: Amariah, Malluch, Hattush,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shecaniah, Rehum, Meremoth,
speaker: Narrator

text: Iddo, Ginnethon, Abijah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Mijamin, Moadiah, Bilgah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Shemaiah, Joiarib, Jedaiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Sallu, Amok, Hilkiah, and Jedaiah. These were the leaders of the priests and their colleagues in the days of Jeshua.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Levites: Jeshua, Binnui, Kadmiel, Sherebiah, Judah, and Mattaniah, who together with his colleagues was in charge of the songs of thanksgiving.
speaker: Narrator

text: Bakbukiah and Unni, their colleagues, stood opposite them in the services.
speaker: Narrator

text: Jeshua was the father of Joiakim, Joiakim was the father of Eliashib, Eliashib was the father of Joiada,
speaker: Narrator

text: Joiada was the father of Jonathan, and Jonathan was the father of Jaddua.
speaker: Narrator

text: In the days of Joiakim, these were the priests who were leaders of the families: of Seraiah, Meraiah; of Jeremiah, Hananiah;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Ezra, Meshullam; of Amariah, Jehohanan;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Malluch, Jonathan; of Shecaniah, Joseph;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Harim, Adna; of Meremoth, Helkai;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Iddo, Zechariah; of Ginnethon, Meshullam;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Abijah, Zicri; of Miniamin and of Moadiah, Piltai;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Bilgah, Shammua; of Shemaiah, Jehonathan;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Joiarib, Mattenai; of Jedaiah, Uzzi;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Sallu, Kallai; of Amok, Eber;
speaker: Narrator

text: of Hilkiah, Hashabiah; of Jedaiah, Nethanel.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the Levites, in the days of Eliashib, Joiada, Johanan and Jaddua the heads of families were recorded, as were the priests during the reign of Darius the Persian.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Levi were recorded in the Book of the Chronicles as heads of families up to the days of Johanan son of Eliashib.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the leaders of the Levites were Hashabiah, Sherebiah, Jeshua son of Kadmiel, and their colleagues, who stood opposite them to offer praise and thanks, one contingent corresponding to the other, as specified by David the man of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: Mattaniah, Bakbukiah, Obadiah, Meshullam, Talmon, and Akkub were gatekeepers who were guarding the storerooms at the gates.
speaker: Narrator

text: These all served in the days of Joiakim son of Jeshua, the son of Jozadak, and in the days of Nehemiah the governor and of Ezra the priestly scribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: At the dedication of the wall of Jerusalem, they sought out the Levites from all the places they lived to bring them to Jerusalem to celebrate the dedication joyfully with songs of thanksgiving and songs accompanied by cymbals, harps, and lyres.
speaker: Narrator

text: The singers were also assembled from the district around Jerusalem and from the settlements of the Netophathites
speaker: Narrator

text: and from Beth Gilgal and from the fields of Geba and Azmaveth, for the singers had built settlements for themselves around Jerusalem.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the priests and Levites had purified themselves, they purified the people, the gates, and the wall.
speaker: Narrator

text: I brought the leaders of Judah up on top of the wall, and I appointed two large choirs to give thanks. One was to proceed on the top of the wall southward toward the Dung Gate.
speaker: Narrator

text: Going after them were Hoshaiah, half the leaders of Judah,
speaker: Narrator

text: Azariah, Ezra, Meshullam,
speaker: Narrator

text: Judah, Benjamin, Shemaiah, Jeremiah,
speaker: Narrator

text: some of the priests with trumpets, Zechariah son of Jonathan, the son of Shemaiah, the son of Mattaniah, the son of Micaiah, the son of Zaccur, the son of Asaph,
speaker: Narrator

text: and his colleagues—Shemaiah, Azarel, Milalai, Gilalai, Maai, Nethanel, Judah, and Hanani—with musical instruments of David the man of God. (Ezra the scribe led them.)
speaker: Narrator

text: They went over the Fountain Gate and continued directly up the steps of the City of David on the ascent to the wall. They passed the house of David and continued on to the Water Gate toward the east.
speaker: Narrator

text: The second choir was proceeding in the opposite direction. I followed them, along with half the people, on top of the wall, past the Tower of the Ovens to the Broad Wall,
speaker: Narrator

text: over the Ephraim Gate, the Jeshanah Gate, the Fish Gate, the Tower of Hananel, and the Tower of the Hundred, to the Sheep Gate. They stopped at the Gate of the Guard.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the two choirs that gave thanks took their stations in the temple of God. I did also, along with half the officials with me,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the priests—Eliakim, Maaseiah, Miniamin, Micaiah, Elioenai, Zechariah, and Hananiah, with their trumpets—
speaker: Narrator

text: and also Maaseiah, Shemaiah, Eleazar, Uzzi, Jehohanan, Malkijah, Elam, and Ezer. The choirs sang loudly under the direction of Jezrahiah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on that day they offered great sacrifices and rejoiced, for God had given them great joy. The women and children also rejoiced. The rejoicing in Jerusalem could be heard from far away.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day men were appointed over the storerooms for the contributions, firstfruits, and tithes, to gather into them from the fields of the cities the portions prescribed by the law for the priests and the Levites, for the people of Judah took delight in the priests and Levites who were ministering.
speaker: Narrator

text: They performed the service of their God and the service of purification, along with the singers and gatekeepers, according to the commandment of David and his son Solomon.
speaker: Narrator

text: For long ago, in the days of David and Asaph, there had been directors for the singers and for the songs of praise and thanks to God.
speaker: Narrator

text: So in the days of Zerubbabel and in the days of Nehemiah, all Israel was contributing the portions for the singers and gatekeepers, according to the daily need. They also set aside the portion for the Levites, and the Levites set aside the portion for the descendants of Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: On that day the book of Moses was read aloud in the hearing of the people. They found written in it that no Ammonite or Moabite may ever enter the assembly of God,
speaker: Narrator

text: for they had not met the Israelites with food and water, but instead had hired Balaam to curse them. (Our God, however, turned the curse into blessing.)
speaker: Narrator

text: When they heard the law, they removed from Israel all who were of mixed ancestry.
speaker: Narrator

text: But before this time, Eliashib the priest, a relative of Tobiah, had been appointed over the storerooms of the temple of our God.
speaker: Narrator

text: He made for himself a large storeroom where previously they had been keeping the grain offering, the incense, and the vessels, along with the tithes of the grain, the new wine, and the olive oil as commanded for the Levites, the singers, the gatekeepers, and the offering for the priests.
speaker: Narrator

text: During all this time I was not in Jerusalem, for in the thirty-second year of King Artaxerxes of Babylon, I had gone back to the king. After some time I had requested leave of the king,
speaker: Narrator

text: and I returned to Jerusalem. Then I discovered the evil that Eliashib had done for Tobiah by supplying him with a storeroom in the courts of the temple of God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I was very upset, and I threw all of Tobiah’s household possessions out of the storeroom.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then I gave instructions that the storerooms should be purified, and I brought back the equipment of the temple of God, along with the grain offering and the incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: I also discovered that the portions for the Levites had not been provided, and that as a result the Levites and the singers who performed this work had all gone off to their fields.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I registered a complaint with the leaders, asking, “Why is the temple of God neglected?” Then I gathered them and reassigned them to their positions.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then all of Judah brought the tithe of the grain, the new wine, and the olive oil to the storerooms.
speaker: Narrator

text: I gave instructions that Shelemiah the priest, Zadok the scribe, and a certain Levite named Pedaiah be put in charge of the storerooms, and that Hanan son of Zaccur, the son of Mattaniah, be their assistant, for they were regarded as trustworthy. It was then their responsibility to oversee the distribution to their colleagues.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please remember me for this, O my God, and do not wipe out the kindness that I have done for the temple of my God and for its services!
speaker: Narrator

text: In those days I saw people in Judah treading winepresses on the Sabbath, bringing in heaps of grain and loading them onto donkeys, along with wine, grapes, figs, and all kinds of loads, and bringing them to Jerusalem on the Sabbath day. So I warned them on the day that they sold these provisions.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people from Tyre who lived there were bringing fish and all kinds of merchandise and were selling it on the Sabbath to the people of Judah—and in Jerusalem, of all places!
speaker: Narrator

text: So I registered a complaint with the nobles of Judah, saying to them, “What is this evil thing that you are doing, profaning the Sabbath day?
speaker: Narrator

text: Isn’t this the way your ancestors acted, causing our God to bring on them and on this city all this misfortune? And now you are causing even more wrath on Israel, profaning the Sabbath like this!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the evening shadows began to fall on the gates of Jerusalem before the Sabbath, I ordered the doors to be closed. I further directed that they were not to be opened until after the Sabbath. I positioned some of my young men at the gates so that no load could enter on the Sabbath day.
speaker: Narrator

text: The traders and sellers of all kinds of merchandise spent the night outside Jerusalem once or twice.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I warned them and said, “Why do you spend the night by the wall? If you repeat this, I will forcibly remove you!” From that time on they did not show up on the Sabbath.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then I directed the Levites to purify themselves and come and guard the gates in order to keep the Sabbath day holy.
For this please remember me, O my God, and have pity on me in keeping with your great love.
speaker: Narrator

text: Also in those days I saw the men of Judah who had married women from Ashdod, Ammon, and Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Half their children spoke the language of Ashdod (or the language of one of the other peoples mentioned) and were unable to speak the language of Judah.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I entered a complaint with them. I called down a curse on them, and I struck some of the men and pulled out their hair. I had them swear by God saying, “You will not marry off your daughters to their sons, and you will not take any of their daughters as wives for your sons or for yourselves.
speaker: Narrator

text: Was it not because of things like these that King Solomon of Israel sinned? Among the many nations there was no king like him. He was loved by his God, and God made him king over all Israel. But the foreign wives made even him sin!
speaker: Narrator

text: Should we then in your case hear that you do all this great evil, thereby being unfaithful to our God by marrying foreign wives?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now one of the sons of Joiada son of Eliashib the high priest was a son-in-law of Sanballat the Horonite. So I banished him from my sight.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please remember them, O my God, because they have defiled the priesthood, the covenant of the priesthood, and the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So I purified them of everything foreign, and I assigned specific duties to the priests and the Levites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
I also provided for the wood offering at the appointed times and also for the firstfruits.
Please remember me for good, O my God.
speaker: Narrator
